Award.AwardTitle: IBSS-Ex: Wealth, Wealth Inequality, and Marraige Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary research project focuses on relationships among wealth, wealth inequality, and polygyny in three population groups (farmers, horticulturalists, and foragers), with special emphasis given to addressing different marriage systems among different cultures. Distribution of different marriage systems has been a focus of anthropological investigation since the discipline's birth, with explanations drawing on sex ratio, women's economic contributions to production, social complexity, fraternal interest groups, available habitats for expansion, and parasite loads. Given the importance of marriage as an economic institution, economic explanations have come to prominence. These explanations show an interesting convergence with ideas developed by behavioral ecologists studying the distribution of polygyny in non-human species. It is widely thought that polygyny will be more common where material wealth is both more unequally held among men and more important to a population's production and reproduction. While this intuition explains why horticulturalists tend to be more polygynous than foragers, it results in a paradox, because farmers, among whom material wealth is both more important and more unequally distributed, are less polygynous than horticulturalists. The project will draw on insights from demography, anthropology, and economics. The researchers will combine ethnographic data with mathematical models of the interacting dynamics of family structure and wealth disparity. The major empirical component of this project entails estimating key model parameters using individual-level data from 13 small-scale populations. The analyses of data from these different sources will allow determination of the relative strengths of these joint effects of different factors and provide a test of possible resolutions of the polygyny paradox.

This project will contribute to basic understanding of the dynamics of disparities in wealth and how they impact on the social structures. The resolution of the polygyny paradox has implications for general knowledge about interactions between wealth and family structure that extend beyond the small scale societies that the project will study. Project results may help address a range of factors that influence marriage dynamics in modern advanced societies, such as a tendency for higher divorce rates and more socially acceptable forms of polygyny, such as individuals having multiple spouses through a series of monogamous marriages over time. The project also will advance the methodological use of mathematical modeling, experimental techniques, and intensive analysis of individual level data to address the trade-off between the depth of an ethnographer's individual-level data and the power of cross-population comparisons. Broader impacts of this project will include facilitation of interdisciplinary research across economics, anthropology and evolutionary biology, special education and training opportunities for a post-doctoral researcher, and annual meetings to advance the use of advanced methodologies tested in this project among scholars in relevant fields. This project is supported through the NSF Interdisciplinary Behavioral and Social Sciences Research (IBSS) competition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All over the world people marry, but forms of marriage vary widely between different cultures and across history. One major dimension of this variability is whether men (and less commonly women) can take more than one spouse at the same time (respectively polygyny and polyandry). Polygyny and monogamy are associated with distinct patterns of wealth inheritance and inequalities. An understanding of the dynamics of marriage systems, particularly with respect to inequalities in wealth and opportunity, will allow us to understand the role of this ancient custom in our modern world and, more formally, to examine the joint evolution of wealth inequality and family structure.

We are a group of evolutionary anthropologists, economists and biologists who are tackling what we call the “polygyny paradox”. The puzzle is this: despite the fact that nearly all previous theoretical work in economics, biology and anthropology suggests that societies that are more unequal in terms of wealth will be more polygynous, monogamy typically characterizes highly unequal agrarian states, while many horticultural economies with less unequal wealth distributions are often highly polygynous.  

We built a model which differentiates rival from non-rival wealth; while the latter, for example the value of a family name, can be given to all offspring in equal measure without dilution, rival wealth (such as land or a herd of cattle) must be divided among offspring. A key consideration for our model is how important these resources (rival and non-rival wealth) are for the reproductive success of both male and female marital partners.

In addition to this model itself, the originality of our work lies in testing model predictions with data on inequality in holdings of rival and non-rival wealth, as well as the effects of each wealth type on men’s reproductive success, using individual records drawn from 25 different small scale societies ranging from foragers, to pastoralists to farmers. For example, our model shows that as the reproductive importance of rival wealth increases, so too does the frequency of monogamy, challenging the old idea that polygyny is simply an expression of wealth inequality among males.  Empirically calibrated simulations using data from an African pastoralist population demonstrate that increasing wealth importance could lead to the emergency of monogamy in previously polygynous society.

We also found that a standard measure of inequality (the Gini coefficient) does not adequately capture the influence of wealth disparities on marital patterns. One dimension of wealth inequality is the ratio of wealth held by rich individuals to the wealth held by poor individuals (the wealth ratio). Another dimension is the frequency of rich and poor individuals.

 Our empirical results show that while an increase in the wealth ratio and a decrease in the frequency of rich people both increase the Gini coefficient, the former is statistically associated with higher levels polygyny (as expected) but the latter is associated with less common polygyny (since only a few men are rich enough to gain a second wife). This suggests that societies with a large fraction of non-rich individuals are likely to be both monogamous and at the same time characterized by high wealth inequality. As such the decline in polygyny that accompanied the transition to agriculture may have been driven not simply by the societies’ dependence on highly rival wealth (such as land) but also by class stratification, particularly by the concentration of land ownership in a small polygynous class and a large class of land poor and monogamous peasants.

We have created, for public use, unique estimates of wealth inequality, wealth importance, and the age-adjusted frequency of polygyny, a major contribution to the on-going empirical study of diverse economic and family systems.

At our two workshops hosted by the Santa Fe Institute we have provided training and networking opportunities for junior faculty, postdocs and graduate students interesting in model building and empirical analysis, constituting a new team of scientists integrated by shared methods and joint research experience. More broadly we are promoting a tradition, based out the Santa Fe Institute, that encourages field anthropologists working at diverse sites to systematize data collection guided by formal models of social and biological dynamics, thereby laying the basis for a truly comparative study of our species, based on individual-level data. Our interdisciplinary community-building is  a major development in the field of anthropology, which long ago distinguished itself in attempting to compile comparative data (http://hraf.yale.edu).

We intend to use our publically funded research findings to discuss these issues in a public blog (such as https://theconversation.com) in which we will discuss competing explanations for the emergence of monogamy, the insights afforded by our model into the association between class structure (not simply inequality) and competitive success (in this case over wives) and the phenomenon of serial monogamy (which is in many economic respects similar to polygyny) among the wealthy in modern society.
